thread.title: Lens aimed at Israel, West Bank when Norton unveils ‘This Place’
thread.title_full: Lens aimed at Israel, West Bank when Norton unveils ‘This Place’

title: Lens aimed at Israel, West Bank when Norton unveils ‘This Place’
text:
Palm Beach Post Staff Writer Lens aimed at Israel, West Bank when Norton unveils ‘This Place’ 12:00 a.m. Thursday, Oct. 8, 2015 | Filed in: Things to Do Comments 0 ﻿ 
A diverse and fragmented portrait of Israel and the West Bank will unfold inside the Norton Museum on Thursday when “This Place: Israel Through Photography’s Lens” makes its U.S. premiere. 
The show is the brainchild of French photographer Frederic Brenner who asked a group of prominent international photographers if they’d like to spend time in Israel and the West Bank to create portraits of the area. Eleven took him up on the offer. 
While the exhibition acknowledges and pays heed to the region’s conflicts, it asks that viewers look beyond this to observe the dozen contemporary photographic viewpoints of Israel and the West Bank, created primarily between 2009 and 2012, according to a release. 
“When what is at stake is sharing the origin,” says Brenner in a statement, “it seems to me necessary to gather a large spectrum of individuals whose origins, passions, and paradoxical and contradictory perspectives could help us grasp the unbearable complexity of this place and its voices.” 
Participating photographers were Brenner (France), Wendy Ewald (United States), Martin Kollar (Slovakia), Josef Koudelka (Czech Republic), Jungjin Lee (S. Korea), Gilles Peress (France), Fazal Sheikh (United States), Stephen Shore (United States), Rosalind Fox Solomon (United States), Thomas Struth (Germany), Jeff Wall (Canada) and Nick Waplington (United Kingdom). 
Brenner is scheduled to give a lecture at 6:30 p.m. Thursday during Art After Dark, and he returns on Nov. 19 for a presentation with other participating photographers. 
IF YOU GO 
“This Place: Israel Through Photography’s Lens” 
When: Thursday to Jan. 17; closed Mondays 
Where: Norton Museum of Art, West Palm Beach 
Cost: Adults, $12; students, $5; children 12 and under, free. Saturday admission free to county residents
